title: M4 MacBook Air, Mac Studio, M3 iPad Air: Everything Apple Could Announce At Their March Event
description: M4 MacBook Air, Mac Studio, M3 iPad Air: Everything Apple Could Announce At Their March EventApple’s product roadmap for 2025 is packed with major updates, spanning everything from MacBooks to iPads and even potential smart home devices. The iPhone 16e...
author: Sarang Sheth
excerpt: Apple’s product roadmap for 2025 is packed with major updates, spanning everything from MacBooks to iPads and even potential smart home devices. The iPhone 16e
text: Apple’s product roadmap for 2025 is packed with major updates, spanning everything from MacBooks to iPads and even potential smart home devices. The iPhone 16e has already arrived, sparking debate over whether it’s a replacement for the iPhone SE or the start of a new product category. Some see it as a budget-friendly alternative with flagship features, while others view it as a refined mid-tier option that doesn’t quite fit the SE’s legacy. Either way, it’s the first of many devices Apple has lined up before summer. The biggest hardware shifts are set to happen in Apple’s Mac lineup, with the MacBook Air, Mac Studio, and Mac Pro all in line for upgrades. A new entry-level iPad is also on the way, along with a refreshed iPad Air sporting an M3 chip. The long-rumored Apple home device could finally see the light of day, while the Studio Display refresh has reportedly been pushed to 2026. There’s also growing speculation about a March event, where some of these products could be officially unveiled. MacBook Air M4: A Power Boost Without a Redesign Apple’s MacBook Air is about to get the M4 chip, signaling another performance boost without any major design changes. According to reports, stock of the M3 MacBook Air is dwindling, a telltale sign that Apple is ready to push its next-gen model. The 13.6-inch and 15.6-inch models will likely retain the same chassis, but potential upgrades include a better camera, a nano-texture display option, and 16GB RAM as the new standard. Storage could remain at 256GB for the base model, which might disappoint some users, especially as the MacBook Pro now starts at 512GB. Battery life is expected to see an increase of 1–2 hours, thanks to the M4’s efficiency improvements. The 13-inch model could feature a “bin” version of the M4 at launch (a ‘bin’ chip is a chip that operates with lower processing power), while the 15-inch model will come with the fully enabled chip. RAM configurations are rumored to include 16GB, 24GB, and 32GB, aligning with the M4 MacBook Pro. Mac Studio and Mac Pro: The Desktop Workhorses Get an Upgrade Apple’s Mac Studio is expected to get a refresh at WWDC 2025, introducing the M4 Max and M4 Ultra chips. The M4 Ultra will likely double the core count of the M4 Max, following Apple’s usual performance scaling. However, there are rumors that Apple may be moving away from unified chip stacking in favor of a completely new architecture. On the design front, changes will be minimal, with the biggest upgrade being Thunderbolt 5 ports on models equipped with the M4 Max and Ultra. A space black color option could also be introduced. Pricing is expected to remain at $2,000 for M4 Max models and $4,000 for M4 Ultra. The Mac Pro, which will also feature the M4 Ultra, is expected to arrive later in 2025, reinforcing Apple’s commitment to high-end desktop performance. Studio Display Delay and Apple’s Smart Home Push The Studio Display, which still relies on a panel design from the 2017 iMac, will reportedly not be refreshed until 2026. This means that users hoping for a higher refresh rate, HDR support, or better color accuracy will have to wait at least another year. Meanwhile, Apple appears to be doubling down on smart home technology. A new HomeKit-powered device is rumored to be in development, designed to integrate with security cameras and other smart home accessories. This could be Apple’s answer to Google’s Nest Hub or Amazon’s Echo Show, with an emphasis on privacy and ecosystem control. There are also whispers of a new Apple TV launching alongside an updated tvOS at WWDC 2025. iPad Updates: A New Budget iPad and M3 iPad Air A successor to the iPad 10th Gen is in the works, likely featuring an A18 chip instead of the A17 Pro. This decision is reportedly tied to USB 2.0 compatibility, as both the iPhone 16e and current base iPad use USB 2.0. The price could increase to $499, but the upgrade from A14 to A18 would represent a four-generation leap, bringing improved performance and efficiency. The iPad Air is also due for an upgrade, moving from M2 to M3. This keeps it one step behind the M4-powered iPad Pro, maintaining Apple’s usual chip hierarchy. Apple is also expected to release a new Magic Keyboard, finally adding function keys, which have been missing since the original iPad Pro Magic Keyboard from 2020. Apple’s immediate 2025 lineup is shaping up to be an M4-driven refresh across MacBooks and desktops, with notable improvements to the iPad lineup and a possible HomeKit expansion. The Studio Display delay and the staggered approach to launches indicate Apple is pacing itself with its updates. Whether these products arrive through a March event or a series of press releases, there’s plenty to look forward to in the coming months.
